title: Estée Lauder Stock Is Surging, and the Lauder Family Just Unloaded a Lot of Shares
text:
Text size

Estée Lauder stock is having a beauty of a year, and the founder’s family recently unloaded a large amount of shares of the maker of upscale cosmetics.

Estée Lauder stock (ticker: EL) has surged 49.7% in 2019 through Friday’s close, more than twice the 20.0% rise in the S&P 500. It topped the index last year, as well, managing a gain of 2.2% in a volatile 2018, while the index slipped 6.2%.

CEO Fabrizio Freda told us last month, in the wake of a strong fiscal-fourth-quarter report, that well-heeled Asian customers were a key component of the growth in Estée Lauder’s retail travel products. “Awareness and visibility of our brand are high, and travelers are very heavy buyers, they are fantastic customers,” he said.

LAL Family Partners, a limited partnership owned by the family of Chairman Emeritus Leonard A. Lauder, one of Estée Lauder’s sons, sold 2 million of the publicly traded Class A shares on Sept. 4 for $392 million, a price of $196 per share. The LALFP, as the partnership is known, sold the stock after converting 2 million class B Estée Lauder shares into the equivalent number of Class A shares, according to a form it filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. LALFP now owns 86.4 million class B shares.

Editor's Choice

Class B shares, which are owned by members of the Lauder family and don’t trade publicly, carry 10 votes each, while the Class A shares carry one each. Each class B share is convertible into in a class A share at the option of the holder, and automatically convert when transferred to a person outside the Lauder family.

In September 2018, LALFP owned 88.9 million class B Estée Lauder shares, 62.1% of the outstanding class B shares and 53.7% of the total voting power of the company.

LALFP’s contact information on its SEC forms is the same as Estée Lauder’s. In response to a request for comment, the company provided a statement: “From time to time, stockholders such as LALFP may sell shares for purposes of financial portfolio diversification; for example, in February 2019, LALFP sold 422,056 shares of Class A Common Stock. The amount of shares sold on Sept. 4, 2019, was in fact less than 3% of LALFP’s total holdings. After these sales, LALFP’s holdings have an aggregate value in excess of $17 billion, based on the closing price on the date of the sales.”

Inside Scoop is a regular Barron’s feature covering stock transactions by corporate executives and board members—so-called insiders—as well as large shareholders, politicians, and other prominent figures. Due to their insider status, these investors are required to disclose stock trades with the Securities and Exchange Commission or other regulatory groups.
